thread.title: Soulfest 2015: Poor tickets sales cause shock festival cancellation
thread.title_full: Soulfest 2015: Poor tickets sales cause shock festival cancellation

author: Kylie Northover
title: Soulfest 2015: Poor tickets sales cause shock festival cancellation
text:
Click to play video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Video will begin in 5 seconds.

Soulfest line-up announcement Promotion of Soulfest's confirmed acts, as listed before it had to cancel its 2015 run.
PT1M4S http://www.canberratimes.com.au/action/externalEmbeddedPlayer?id=d-44ia5 620 349 October 14, 2015 - 2:28PM Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Lauryn Hill joins Soulfest In shock news for music fans, the second annual SoulFest music festival has been cancelled just a week away before the first date.
Featuring an A-list line-up of soul music stars, including Mary J Blige, Lauryn Hill, Mos Def, De La Soul and Miguel, the festival was slated to begin its run next week in Auckland before further dates in Melbourne, Sydney as well as side shows in Brisbane, Melbourne and Sydney.
Hip-hop legends De La Soul. Photo: Supplied 
Announcing the news on their Facebook page, SoulFest organisers said the event has been cancelled due to poor ticket sales. The festival's website was updated mid-morning with the same message.
Advertisement "It is with a heavy heart and great regret that Soulfest International advises that it has become necessary to cancel Soulfest and the subsequent sideshows, due to poor ticket sales," the statement reads.
Organisers went on to say that the festival was launched with the intention of promoting genres of music "often overlooked commercially in this country, specifically Neo-Soul, RnB and Hip-Hop, and SoulFest 2014 successfully delivered some of the most exciting talent within these genres".
Miguel was also set to perform at SoulFest 2015. Photo: supplied 
But despite the stellar line-up for the 2015 event, this year's ticket sales were so bad that "the financial loss that would would be incurred by the event if it were to go ahead as planned would be devastating", organisers said.
"There have been many people working behind the scenes, including media partners, artists, sponsors, sub-contracted promoters, communication managers, agents and suppliers who live, breathe and support this incredible genre of music and have worked tirelessly to try and make this event a success.
"The promoter of SoulFest International Australia, John Denison, sincerely apologizes (sic) to all involved who have dedicated 7 months of their lives to work on this festival, and to the supporters of the event who purchased tickets."
Mary J Blige performs at a British music festival in July. Photo: Samir Hussein 
It's not the first time festival promoter John Denison has disappointed artists and fans - local acts booked for the Melbourne leg of the 2014 SoulFest were angered by a last minute decision to cancel the event's "local stage".
"Due to a combination of operational and logistical issues - the local stage will not be operating today. All local artists will not be appearing. We apologize (sic)  to our local artists and the punters for this inconvenience," a Facebook post at the time read.
But that was small-fry compared to the promoter's previous festival, Supafest. In April 2012, Denison and his then business partner Dwayne Cross pulled three advertised headline acts from the line-up of Supafest , billed as "Australia's largest hip-hop festival", which they first staged in 2010.
At the time, Supafest organisers released a statement saying P Diddy and Missy Elliott's performances were cancelled due to poor ticket sales.
But Missy Elliott claimed she was falsely advertised as a headliner, having not signed a contract, while P Diddy (also known as Sean Combes) took to Twitter to say he was "mad as f--k" at what he described as a breach of contract by Supafest organisers.
"The promoters never sent the money for the show i love you guys!" he tweeted to his five million followers.
"@SupaFest2012 stop playing around and come thru with what you agreed to in the contract!!! Don't cheat the people givem what dey want," he tweeted.
The festival went ahead - Chris Brown, Ice Cube and Kelly Rowland were among the acts who played - but ticket sales were, as one might expect, lower than Mr Denison might have liked.
Shortly afterwards, in May 2012, Paper Chase Touring and Entertainment, the major partner in Supafest, was being chased by several creditors, including the The Phonographic Performance Company of Australia , which collects royalties for artists, who were seeking $13,200 in unpaid fees.
Then in October, Mr Denison was sued by A-League soccer club Melbourne Victory for unpaid fees for a soccer friendly against Greek team Olympiakos.
According to documents lodged in the Supreme Court of Victoria, Mr Denison had "agreed to pay Melbourne Victory the sum of $110,000 on or before 31 July 2012".
In February 2013, Supafest collapsed and administrators were appointed to Supafest and Paperchase Touring and Entertainment, with the company owing debts in excess of $2 million.
The SoulFest website states that "no further statement or comments will be issued".
Last year's inaugural SoulFest, which featured D'Angelo, Common, Aloe Blacc, Leela James and Angie Stone among its diverse line-up was well received by fans and critics.
While angry Australian and New Zealand fans have taken to Twitter to vent their disappointment, so far none of the artists scheduled to play have posted any reactions on social media.
Ticket holders will be offered full refunds; for details check soulfest.com.au

Posted by Soulfest on Tuesday, 13 October 2015
